headline: Easy Small-Batch Blueberry Jam
description: This blueberry jam recipe uses just 4 ingredients and no pectin to make a homemade preserve that's sweet and spreadable with lots of blueberry flavor.

video.name: How to Make Easy Blueberry Jam

name: Easy Small-Batch Blueberry Jam

recipeInstructions.text: Mix blueberries, sugar, lemon juice, and cinnamon in a saucepan. Cook, stirring constantly, over medium heat until thickened, about 30 minutes.

I followed the recipe exactly (no cinnamon) and it turned out perfectly. I simmered it about 20 minutes stirring often. It is very thick and it tastes delicious. I wish I could share a photo but I can’t get it to upload.
I cut the sugar down to 1/2cup and gave a few quick blends with a hand blender. Really nice recipe.

This is a good, basic recipe but there is a bit too much sugar in my opinion. That is easily remedies, just add more or less to your personal taste preference.
I saw a few comments about doing the upside down method of sealing your jars. This is a very bad idea. This does not always seal properly even though you will think it did, possible and even probably allowing harmful bacteria to enter the jar. Please only use proper canning methods (like a water bath) to seal your jars properly. Yes it is more work but far, far safer for you and your family.
So easy. The constant stirring was a pain, but it came out beautifully.
Great recipe! Definitely makes small batch. Made 3 pints- perfect for a quick recipe after a small picking of 4 cups of fruit! No pectin.. awesome!

Just finished making this and it turned out great. I only took off one star because it actually took over one hour to reduce to the right consistency. Thanks to a previous reviewer I knew how to gauge proper thickness without relying on the time. Her suggestion of cooking until when stir there’s a delay in the liquid coming together again, enough that you see the pan bottom. Hope this helps someone else. Otherwise, thanks for a simple recipe I will definitely use again.
Loved it! So easy! I added three tablespoons of lemon juice because I wanted it a little more sour and I kept it on heat for about 40 minutes to thicken it up more. Came out great :)

Love this nice simple recipe that makes delicious jam. I want to add the information from another reviewer about prepping the jars. Wash the jars with soap and water and rinse thoroughly. Place in a large deep pot and fill the pot and jars with water. Bring to a boil and allow to simmer vigorously for 15 minutes. Turn off and leave jars in the water until ready to fill. At the same time place the lids in a small saucepan and arrange so they are not stuck together. Cover with a couple inches of water and bring to a boil for 15 minutes. Set metal tongs in the pan. This can all happen while berries are cooking. The idea is that the jars and everything touching the jam is as sterile as possible. This will avoid any of the mishaps you sometimes hear about home canned food.
It taste and looks amazing! I left mine more chunky though. Thanks for helping me impress my mom, score!

I made this using 1/4 of the ingredients for a taste test. I didn't have lemon juice so I used cranberry juice instead. It was delicious. I will make the suggested amount and try the lemon juice next time. Loved it!
Mom loved it
Way to dry and chunky . Not enough sugar- needs at least 4 cups. Terrible recipe
The easiest jam I made all summer. Idiot-proof. Tastes great, though used a lot more lemon juice.
I made this recipe exactly how it is stated except for I did can it instead it was literally the best blueberry jam I've ever had and now I want to put it in a pie
Very tasty! Family loved it over biscuits.

So easy! Thanks for the spoon trick! I reduced this down to 4 servings, and it was cooked in 10 min. If I hadn’t read that review it’d def be overcooked! My picky SO loved it! Will be adding to the recipe book for sure!
to much sugar recommend using half of the sugar or adding about 2 more cups of blueberries.

I made this jam twice, doubling the recipe each time. I used 8 cups of berries and puréed them in the food processor for a few seconds until the berries were chunky, but broken down. 
The first time I made this recipe, I cooked it too long in an attempt to reach that magic jam setting temperature of 105 Celsius. It turned out too thick and too sweet for my liking. It’s still useable, but I wanted a softer set with the blueberry taste at the forefront, not the sugar. 
The second attempt I was much more successful. I paid more attention to the time and cooked it for just 25 minutes, heeding the advice of other reviewers. It was exactly perfect. Just what I was looking for. I canned three jars and put a fourth in the fridge to enjoy now. This recipe is definitely a keeper. I should also mention that I tried 3 other recipes and have done a side by side taste comparison. My family and I all agree that this is one by far superior.
Love this recipe. Super easy to make since this was my first time. I added Lemon Zest.

I made this with splenda sugar to make it better for my health but even so it turned out delicious. I will be using it for toast and pancakes and oatmeal too. It thickened well and was done before the 30 minutes but I also had around 3 cups of blueberries instead of 4. I like that you can make it the consistency you want. For those that say it didn't thicken I think they probably did not leave it long enough and you do have to continuously stir so that it doesn't clump in parts and burn. I don't know if the pinch of cinnamon did much to the flavoring but I added it in anyways. I recommend this recipe! Thank you so much!

 Side Note: It probably tastes even better with real sugar lol.
11 Cups of Blueberries, adjusted ingredients accordingly, cooked 40 minutes and gave them a little smashing to help.
I loved it! it was the perfect amount of sweet and tart. my family thinks it's a great recipe and I will definitely be making it again!

I only had 3/4 cup of blueberries so I had to reduce everything by a lot, including the cooking time. 
This turned out quite well! Just do not use the bottled lemon juice. That makes this taste slightly stale.
This is so simple and delicious. It' was so good hot over a homemade biscuit. Also, I used lime juice instead of lemon. Really great recipe!

I doubled this recipe, and misread the instructions, cooking it over high heat. It set up in less than the 30 minutes called for here. For people who are having a hard time getting it to set, maybe try raising the heat? (Not as much as I did, though, because I was lucky I didn't scorch it)

Simple is right. I made this after picking my blueberry bush and looking for something to do with the berries. The only change I made was I swapped the white sugar for raw sugar and it came out great. I would definately make it again.

This recipe is far too sweet for my liking. I can barely taste any blueberry for all of the sugar, and I used the four fresh cups of blueberries from our bush outside. It’s also very thick - almost unpleasantly so. I followed the recipe and instructions exactly as written.
Super easy and makes a wonderful tasting jam! I accidentally put a little more than a pinch of cinnamon but it still turned out great!

This did not work out. I followed the recipe exactly and it hardened into a big nearly solid chunk of sweetened blueberry. Seems there’s not enough liquid. I used fresh picked blueberries. Not sure how I can save it, I will try adding water and reheating.

This recipe is so easy and makes wonderful jam! I will never purchase store bought jam again. I have made blueberry (which is amazing) and strawberry and they have turned out perfectly. The only thing to note is for me it takes longer than 30 minutes to cook and thicken. In my experience, cook time is approximately 40 minutes in order for the berries to thicken into a jam.
So good!!
My first time making this and it's awesome. Now I will need to make my biscuits or scones
I followed the recipe and it came out great! I will definitely do it again! It’s easy and tasty!
Absolutely lovely jam! First batch I followed the recipe exactly. Turned out perfectly. Second batch I added 1T lemon zest - gave it a nice lemony tartness.

So good. The instructions didn't say to mash the blueberries but I figured you are supposed to. I used less than half the sugar because I like more sour flavor than sweet. It will be great on toast and vegan ice cream. Thank you.
Update: had to come back and edit my review because I just grabbed it out of the fridge to eat plain. So good.

I haven’t tried the end product but I followed the recipe and some of the helpful hints added by other reviewers, and it is definitely jam. I used frozen berries and it took a bit longer to boil down to the right consistency, but it was very easy.
It’s delicious! I made it twice today and the second time it flopped but the first was a win! It comes out super sweet and yummy!

Simple easy recipe that turned out exactly as written. I only had 2 cups of blueberries and just halved the ingredients. I cooked it for 29 minutes, it thickened beautifully. I did not have fresh lemon, so I used a crystallized lemon that I had and it was perfect.
Super easy!!! Amazing taste

It’s was my first time making jam. I made a mistake cooked it a little longer then I should do it ended up a little more solid then it should. But I am still able to eat it and it tastes great. Would make again!

This is SO good! 4 cups of blueberries only makes shy of 2 pints, but I added a teaspoon of vanilla and it totally took it over the top.

Very easy and turned out great. Ended up halving the recipe because I was constrained by the amount of blueberriesI had on hand. I added a pinch of clove and was a little heavy handed on the cinnamon and lemon juice and it came out great!

I made a tiny batch and it was delish. Just enough to spread on four pieces of toast. I used a 6 oz. box of fresh blueberries, which is about 1 cup. Just added 1/4 cup of sugar, 1 Tsp. lemon and a little cinnamon. Because it is a tiny batch, it only took 10 minutes to cook. I like that in a recipe!

I added more lemon juice than the recipe called for, but next time I'd do about 3/4 cup of sugar instead because of how sweet it turned out despite adding more lemon juice. Other than that, it's a handy recipe!

I was cleaning out my freezer, and found several packages of frozen blueberries. Blueberries had gone on sale several times this summer and I planned to eat my surplus as a frozen treat. Needless to say, they were obviously forgotten in the depths of the freezer. I was so pleased to find this recipe and made a double batch. It did take a little longer than the recipe specified to thicken up, probably because I used frozen blueberries. I was going to use the ‘line down the middle’ trick one reviewer suggested, but it never got to that point before I took it off the heat. I ladled it into sterile jars, lightly screwed on lids, and turned them upside down. Sealed like a charm! I had a little left over so we could sample this, and it is so good! I followed the recipe, including a bit of cinnamon. Thanks for this recipe; I will definitely be making this again.

This recipe is so simple and delicious! I cut the recipe in half because I only had 2 cups of blueberries. Thanks to Holly Pena and Jeanette Guymon Walker, I was successful in canning my first jam! My son loves this on his waffles.
It’s so good love a lot

Fortunately I heeded the warnings about the sugar quantities. I made a very large batch with blueberries I picked a few days ago (amazing long picking season this year). I added 3/4 cup of organic cane sugar to 16 cups of fresh organic blueberries and the juice of 1 organic lemon. Not too sweet and definitely not too tart . I canned the resultant jam. Made ~ 80 oz of jam.
no changes to my first batch. Lovely. Let it cook for a little over 35 minutes as I had tripled the batch. Put it into the fridge to store til eaten. Will report if it goes bad before 3 months
excellent recipe!

It all depends on the berries. I went picking at picked sour ones and still used less sugar than called for. I used about 75% of what it recommended. I could see if using sweeter berries to use less sugar or more lemon. It turned out great and I made 3 batches. It shrinks a lot and it takes about 30 mins on the stove. And if you pour quickly into canning jars the heat naturally seals them.
Can out great. I followed the recipe exactly. I ended with about 2 and a 1/2 cups

Followed the recipe using lowbush/wild blueberries. The flavour was good but the blueberry skins were unpleasantly chewy. If I try this again with wild berries, I will cook it for half the time.
